reviewText: If you don't get golf, this movie may not work for you. But if you've done enough golf to realize it for the mental game it is, then this movie will speak to you. But if you've played golf and also done any meditative eastern religion practice, then you'll *really* like this movie. I was recommended this movie by someone who decided to look into meditative/buddhist practices as a result of this movie. Having seen it now, I can see why.
Title: Golf in the Kingdom

reviewText: Few movies have affected me in quite the same way as Susan Streitfeld's adaptation of Michael Murphy's popular novel "Golf in the Kingdom." I don't want to be unkind, but it is a movie that completely misses its mark in a most spectacular way. For the record, I'm a fan of Streitfeld's one other film which was 1996's experimental feminist provocation "Female Perversions." And I have nothing but respect for the source novel, a challenging blend of philosophy and mysticism that would undoubtedly be nearly impossible to bring to the screen effectively. But the film version of "Golf in the Kingdom," despite its talented array of actors and its lovely setting, feels like poorly lit amateur theater where intellectual musings rhapsodize about golf while simultaneously zapping any sense of fun or life out of the game. Even if you absolutely love golf, the film spends little time honoring the game (some characters play golf, but you never actually see golf being played beyond a stroke or two). Instead, the golf course is just one more place for preposterously obtuse philosophical ramblings to take place.The film has many notable names in its cast including Malcolm McDowell, Frances Fisher, Joanne Whalley, and Julian Sands. Unfortunately, none of them have anything to do as they are all stuck at a table in an empty room engaged in endless discourse about the importance of golf. I'm fine with minimalist settings, but these segments are so tedious and pretentious--I'd have welcomed anything to liven them up! Apparently people play golf for all sorts of existential reasons, and no one does so for fun! The part of the movie that works slightly better is out on the course where a brash American (Mason Gamble, grown up from his role as Dennis the Menace) is humbled by a local legend (David O'Hara). O'Hara is actually quite good. As the themes venture into the more mystical realm, he is lively and entertaining. But the staging of everything is so awkward (Streitfeld employs numerous visual tricks like bizarre editing and varying camera speed), it makes the whole project feel especially homemade.I was so uninterested in this film and thought it didn't work on so many levels, I thought surely I must be missing something (especially since I'd definitely recommend the novel to a golfing enthusiast). For the record, though, I started watching the movie with three other guys--all had bailed by the twenty minute mark! I wondered if perhaps others had gotten something from the movie that eluded me. So I did a little research and checked what the critical score was on Metacritic. It didn't have a lot of professional reviews listed, but the five that were there gave the movie an average score of 13 out of 100, the highest individual ranking being 30. Interestingly the quote on the DVD cover from the New York Times really doesn't say much (A mystical tale from tee to green) but I found that I agreed more with the actual review which summed things up thusly: "Everyone spouts nicely turned baloney elevating golf to the level of a religious experience, which grows tedious fairly quickly." I'm not saying that I'm right or these five critics are right, you may well love this movie. My honest recommendation, though, is to see it before you buy it--make sure that it is a film you want to add to your library. KGHarris, 5/12.
summary: Philosophical Ramblings And Tedious Pseudo-Intellectual Musings Make This Unsuccessful Adaptation Almost Unwatchable
Title: Golf in the Kingdom

reviewText: Maybe it's just me but I was bored watching this.  Should have given it a 2 but others might like it so I don't want to downplay it too much.  I have a nice collection of DVD movies and music concerts that I keep.  This one I would give to a friend and not miss it.
Title: Golf in the Kingdom

reviewText: First off, you need to know that I don't play golf and I find watching the sport quite boring, so I didn't approach this film, adapted from Michael Murphy's novel, from that angle. But, like watching the game, this 87-minute film moved VERY slow for me.The story - about Murphy's stop in Scotland on the way to India - and learning the "tao of golf" from the pro Shivas Irons - is not told in a linear format. As we hear in the bonus interviews, it is about the "feeling of playing golf". So I'm sure that golfers will get a lot more from this than non-golfers. And the scenery is gorgeous. (The film was made in the US using FOUR different courses to recreate the one in Burningbush, Scotland.The bonus features are also a bit of a mix: The "Behind the scenes" one (14 minutes) consists of a 9-minute "montage" (basically scenes from filming with no narration) and four short interviews with the cast. The other is an 18-minute interview with Murphy.I'm sure some golfers will add their reviews here, but I wanted to provide the opinion of a non-golfer. And for me the film and DVD was "just okay".I hope you found this information both informative and helpful.Steve Ramm"Anything Phonographic"
summary: Golfers will find this interesting, but it does move slow
Title: Golf in the Kingdom

reviewText: "Michael you have to remember your in the land where all these ruleswere invented. It's the only way you can play in the kingdom." MichaelMurphy (Gamble) is a philosophy student that is searching for himself.His one real love is golf and before he decided to give it up foreverhe stops by Scotland to play in the famous "Links of Burningbush." Ihave said this before but I am a sucker for sports movies. Any kind andgolf is no different. I really enjoyed "Greatest Game Ever Played" &"Bobby Jones". The recent "Seven Days In Utopia" was also fantastic somy expectations were high for this one. While the movie itself is notbad and the scenery is pretty I was very disappointed. This movie ismore of watching the young boy Michael meeting a golf pro named ShivasIrons (O'Hara) who proceeds to teach him about the game. The movie thenbecomes watching Michael get an hour private lesson about golf. Iunderstand the book is great, but I wasn't that entertained by thismovie. It's not bad, I was just hoping for something different.Overall, not bad, but more of movie about the rules and philosophy ofgolf then the sport itself. I give it a B-.
summary: I expected a movie about golf. While it was it is more of watching a kid get a private lesson. I've seen better. B-.
Title: Golf in the Kingdom
